channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Amazon workers in New York voted to form a union. It's the first successful unionization effort by U.S. workers at the tech giant. https://t.co/OrH9t7xmlG

Moscow’s pivot from focusing on Kyiv and cities in the north to seizing parts of the country’s east is an indication of the effectiveness of Ukraine’s resistance and signals a Kremlin decision to pursue what is likely to become a prolonged war of attrition https://t.co/rhoHj56mQJ

From @WSJopinion: Only Russians can remove Putin from power. That is why, in addition to supplying arms to Ukraine, the U.S. needs to take steps to reach the Russian people, writes @DavidSatter. https://t.co/GWYOq29jlV
Russia’s factories cut production and jobs in March after the U.S. and its allies adopted economic sanctions over Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/33ys35Go2s

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky stripped two generals of their rank for what he said was their failure to live up to their oath of allegiance. “I do not have time to deal with all the traitors. But gradually they will all be punished.” https://t.co/0OHoc1XjAj

Pope Francis asked forgiveness for the abuse of Canadian indigenous children at Catholic Church-run residential schools over more than a century. The is part of an extraordinarily elaborate gesture of penitence by the pope. https://t.co/p2CmSSlGL1

Russia’s army has suffered serious losses amid fierce Ukrainian resistance. A less visible failure to supply its troops has hobbled Moscow’s invasion plans, according to Western intelligence. https://t.co/TLXPDdVD4q
The Taliban are asserting control over nongovernmental organizations working in Afghanistan, demanding a greater say over who receives aid https://t.co/MmP7DqNMUF
Foreign donors pledged $2.44 billion in aid to provide relief to millions of Afghans facing hunger, while bypassing the Taliban https://t.co/vfegWEWK98
Ukrainian attack helicopters executed a low-flying predawn raid on Russian territory, a Russian official said, signaling Kyiv’s ability to broaden the field of the war https://t.co/PAIBaH5BwV
Washington Gov. Jay Inslee has signed a bill creating the country's first statewide alert system for missing indigenous people https://t.co/JtIlkmXtyU

A Ukrainian mother fled Syria's war with her baby boy in her arms. A decade later, her 11-year-old son escaped Ukraine alone: “I had already given up on myself, but I wanted him to live.” https://t.co/TOBLhaKIGU

The Razzie Awards, a satirical awards organization that recognizes actors and movies for subpar work, rescinded a worst-performance award it gave to Bruce Willis after the actor’s family said he suffers from aphasia https://t.co/uLSSQ6Xejm
Day after day, Russian forces bombed the city of Mariupol. Hundreds of Ukrainians hid inside a theater where one couple took charge of keeping everyone alive. https://t.co/wxQiiAvNYx

From @WSJopinion: There is hope amid the heartbreaking carnage in Ukraine that one nation’s valiant struggle for survival may bring a rules-based world order closer to realization, writes @JoshuaMuravchik https://t.co/xpRCp0O4lA

Political freedoms and the rule of law have continued to deteriorate in Hong Kong over the past year, threatening American interests and Hong Kong’s autonomy, a State Department report says https://t.co/Khq78QATZn
“Party on the bottom, business on the top.” Employees returning to the office are coming up with new dress codes. https://t.co/vVOw6fiuNo

A former coal company executive from Knoxville, Tenn., was arrested Thursday for his role in an alleged scheme to bribe government officials in Egypt in exchange for contracts with a state-owned company, U.S. prosecutors said https://t.co/zEtAQIoz9E

Before The Weeknd became famous, he rented a one-bedroom with friends. Now he owns a portfolio of properties, including a swanky Bel-Air mansion he purchased for $69 million last year. https://t.co/Pdcnad31zS
From @WSJopinion: The point of the pile-on is to hurt the reputation of Justice Clarence Thomas as part of the larger effort to delegitimize the current Supreme Court https://t.co/vcKyUNvzzN
One more way the pandemic changed offices: Many of the men you work with are balder https://t.co/UlyCR8rjNV

From @WSJopinion: The U.S. can use this opportunity to lure partners away from Russian arms and begin to box Russia out of strategic markets. But it must change its approach, write @RumleyGM and David Schenker https://t.co/e40STDhcFq

The Biden administration will make an additional 35,000 seasonal-worker visas available to employers ahead of the coming summer hiring season, the Department of Homeland Security said Thursday https://t.co/Y8dt29RcaI
GameStop stock jumps 15% after saying it will seek shareholder approval to increase the number of shares for a stock split https://t.co/PXBjASRAgH v

More than a third of U.S. high-school students reported that their mental health was poor during the Covid-19 pandemic, and 44% said they felt sad or hopeless, a CDC survey finds https://t.co/EAmUmd7PYC

Russian forces handed control of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant back to Ukrainian authorities, officials said. Plant workers said the departing troops took more than 100 Ukrainian national guardsmen away in trucks as prisoners of war. https://t.co/fjKdRYP3XF
The House passed legislation aimed at capping the out-of-pocket cost for purchasing insulin at $35 a month https://t.co/sXOnTtQpl9

The Razzie Awards, a satirical awards organization that recognizes actors and movies for subpar work, rescinded a worst-performance award it gave to Bruce Willis after the actor’s family said he suffers from aphasia https://t.co/v8o80OUbAZ
For nearly three weeks, hundreds of Ukrainians hid from Russian bombs and missiles in the Mariupol theater. The miracle was how they cared for one another. https://t.co/W81cER5XMN

A federal judge struck down parts of a sweeping Florida elections law passed last year by the Republican-led state legislature, saying certain measures were unconstitutional and targeted Black voters https://t.co/ya68oqj5yp
Americans will be able to select an X gender designation on their passport applications starting April 11 https://t.co/Q5mebGQWJZ

Americans will be able to select an X gender designation on their passports starting next month, the State Department said, a new option for those who don’t identify as exclusively male or female https://t.co/LRUAPNIgrg

The tiny Persian Gulf kingdom of Qatar is emerging as one of Europe’s best hopes for weaning itself off Russian natural gas, in another sign of how the war in Ukraine is changing the world’s energy relationships https://t.co/n9vVA3RGnZ

Many patients have died in recent days at a large Shanghai elderly-care hospital that is battling a Covid-19 outbreak, a sign that a new wave of infections is hitting China’s financial capital harder than authorities have publicly disclosed https://t.co/DCTRZhIPvb
Scientists say they’ve created the first complete map of a human genetic code. It could help us learn more about human evolution and genetic diseases. https://t.co/ZjV2tDrj5v
Ukrainian factories keep running despite materials shortages and dangers. “If we work we help our land and we help our country.” https://t.co/cgaGpPjEOg
President Biden is expected to tap up to 180 million barrels of government oil reserves over the next six months to address rising energy prices, the White House said https://t.co/bhh6Lw8zLl
Two senior British judges resigned their posts on Hong Kong’s highest court, citing deteriorating freedoms in the city under a Beijing-imposed security law https://t.co/eQhkxIqFdn

NATO members outside the U.S. are set to boost their military spending following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, according to alliance Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg and pledges from member countries https://t.co/g84QgxxMwk

From @WSJopinion: I do not see how the U.S. and its allies can resume normal relations with Russia while Putin’s army enforces a de facto partition of Ukraine, writes @BillGalston. Putin cannot be rewarded for naked aggression. https://t.co/MNyfQWszLS

The Hubble telescope snapped an image showing the most distant individual star ever seen. Dubbed Earendel, the star lies 12.9 billion light-years from Earth and is believed to be about 50 times as massive as the sun. https://t.co/U93J8xfADB

Ukrainian officials said their armed forces are pressing forward against Russian military units around Kyiv, seeking to exploit Moscow’s efforts to regroup after weeks of heavy losses https://t.co/S1MhD2enJ4

Alisher Usmanov is one of Russia’s wealthiest oligarchs and has been sanctioned by the U.S. So why did a shipment of pig iron from one of his companies steam into Alabama early this month? https://t.co/RmzBpAZBwK

Bruce Willis is stepping away from his acting career after being diagnosed with aphasia, a condition that can affect the ability to speak or write, his family said Wednesday. Here’s what to know about the language disorder. https://t.co/6uMv3AKPvZ

“If I’m an American executive still inside of Russia, I would have left yesterday,” a former State Department counterterrorism chief said, as officials warned that Russian authorities have “singled out” U.S. citizens in Russia for harassment https://t.co/ZG5YTrQANY

President Biden is preparing to announce the release of up to 1 million barrels of oil a day from the U.S. strategic petroleum reserve, according to people familiar with the plans https://t.co/qc4qlcR9Pf

The Academy said it asked Will Smith to leave the Oscars after he slapped Chris Rock, and the actor refused. The organization has initiated disciplinary proceedings against Smith that could include suspension, expulsion or other sanctions. https://t.co/fEJelOW5MN

“How was your weekend?” Chris Rock asked fans at his first stand-up show since being slapped by Will Smith at the Oscars, acknowledging the incident only briefly during his set https://t.co/fumRKAQIri

Bruce Willis is stepping away from his acting career after being diagnosed with aphasia, a condition that can affect the ability to speak or write, his family said Wednesday. Here’s what to know about the language disorder. https://t.co/TFDXnid7XD

From @WSJopinion: We trust judges to behave professionally and with integrity when it comes to recusal decisions, and Justice Clarence Thomas has earned our trust, writes @jasonrileywsj https://t.co/fNkKLk5gfZ
